body:
> we should fix these things before we ship

> > It displays an error until you set a range.

Fixed. If no range is set, I set the range to 0-110%.

> > The measure line's color does not get set for some reason.

This was due to the `chart.color((d) => category21(d[colorKey]));` line in `nvd3_vis.js`. I don't have a deeper understanding of this, but I skip this line for the bullet chart now.

> > Would be nice to provide a way to set the ranges/markers from metrics as well.

By this I mean maybe you have two metrics, `SALES` and `SALES_TARGET`. Then you might want to display `SALES` as the progress bar, but put a triangle marker at `SALES_TARGET` instead of a constant. In my current version you can only specify constants.

One easy solution would be to treat non-numeric values in the `markers`/`marker_lines`/`ranges` parameters as metric names. (Maybe also for the labels.) I think I could implement this, but I see no precedent for it. Metrics are always picked from dropdowns, while here the user would have to type the metric name.

What do you think? I guess it would not actively _hurt_ anyone, so I would be inclined to implement this. Of course if you have a better idea, that would be best.

> > The bullet chart is stretched to fill the height of the panel. It looks pretty bad until you resize the panel.

Fixed. Its height is limited to 50px now.

I've been looking into what permissions would be neccesary for the 'public' role to provide access to view dashboards. 

So far, the permissions set:

 	[can show on DashboardModelView, can show on DashboardModelViewAsync, can dashboard on Caravel, can list on DashboardModelView, can list on DashboardModelViewAsync, can edit on DashboardModelViewAsync, can welcome on Caravel]

Solves the TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS error when logging in as a public user, and displays only a dashboard list page. Currently looking at what permission would make some/all dashboards visible to the user.
Oh check out `assets/javascripts/components/Button.jsx` it's basically a bootstrap button with a tooltip prop.

also, we should think about how we are adding vis's and how there is duplication between the front end and backend for field type declarations. would be nice to solve that, but not necessarily a blocker for this PR.

query is formed in models.py [https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/34d0dd9d6e074e41968c39247d66e19fd551c57b/superset/models.py#L1163](url) and returned along with viz object in viz.py [https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/34d0dd9d6e074e41968c39247d66e19fd551c57b/superset/viz.py#L170](url). So to get query before the viz returns we may have to create a new endpoint to return query separately, which I don't think would be necessary since this use case is quite rare?

I think ClickHouse is great alternative for Druid. According to documentation there are 2 ways how to make Superset work with ClickHouse:
1) Native support (similar to Druid)
2) Using SQLAlchemy

Unfortunately there is no external SQLAlchemy dialect for ClickHouse (https://github.com/Infinidat/infi.clickhouse_orm/issues/8). And I think native support would be better. Unfortunately documentation lack description how to do that.
I have make a merge request,https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/1809

@sichkarev Of course it is possible if someone do the work :)
@tomsej If you want to tackle it feel free to ask any question you have, i don't think much code is needed to add a new data sources backend.
@tylerFowler have you analized where the query come from? Is it something that can be optimized in pandas, sqlalchemy or superset?
@xrmx Thank you so much! Where should I start - Models.py?

@tomsej Well it depends. If it exposes a sql interface i'd give a try with the sqlalchemy dialect. If it's not try to come up with something like DruidDatasource. I don't know if it has the same metric, cluster and column entities as Druid though.

Frankly, I wouldn't even know where to look as I'm not familiar with pandas or sqlalchemy. I would imagine it's Superset that's generating the query based off of the graph options, but if I'm mistaken feel free to redirect me to appropriate repo.
i'll review this monday.
thanks for taking this @vera-liu! just a couple comments, but LGTM.
LGTM

@ujhujuh -  it would be great to understand the plan in a bit more details. As dashboard access becomes a bit tricky:
* If user has access to the dashboard, can he explore the slices that belong to the dashboards
* If user has access to the dashboard, can he explore the datasources that are backing up that dashboard
* If user has access to the dashboard, can he apply filters to the dashboard
* If user has access to the dashboard, can he make a copy of the dashboard and modify the copy 
* What happens if the dashboard access gets revoked?

could you also please describe the business use case?
I would love to learn more about it.
This subquery is a feature. It's a byproduct of using the `Series Limit` parameter. Set that parameter to `0` to not generate that subquery.
Let's make sure it behaves as expected on the SQLAlchemy side of things. We don't want a change of behavior where Slices that used to not have a time column have one now....

This has some complex-ish implications and we need to discuss internally whether we want to add this new dimension in the security matrix. For instance what happens now if the person has access to the dashboard but not to the underlying table(s)? What happens to permissions when someone renames a dashboard?
LGTM, thanks for fixing this!
LGTM

i'm wondering about the user experience here, and thinking that we should only show a single run query button for simplicity. If run async is an available option, let's run the query async, if not we run a synchronous query, and in both cases we only show a singe `Run Query` button. thoughts?

additionally, could we make the CTAS button the same color as the run query button? I like jeff's tooltip suggestion but would suggest removing `as` between table and with: `Create table with query results`
Oh I think you can now also remove the `update_chart` endpoint on the backend
I'd love to know if people using Postgres or Redshift confirm that this doesn't break their existing configuration.
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/1671
We need physical segments to extract the column information, can you confirm that both datasources actually have segments?

@ascott - I really like the idea of having a single query button.  We shouldn't have to make users choose.  Rather, we should do the work of identifying what is the right way to run a query.  I'll put this as an item in our backlog

@xrmx we recently met the same issue and had fixed it in our local repo. I've created PR #1821 for it. Please have a review at it, thanks.

The issue is caused by a long standing [IE issue](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/1002846/pathname-incorrect-for-out-of-document-elements). Superset's `Slice.jsonEndpoint()` method relies on DOM element's `pathname()` to build JSON API URL for slices, and in IE <= 11 the return value of out-of-document element lacks a leading '/'.
same test is failing so not related to this test.

LGTM as is, the only thing missing from that issue is to run `resize` when window is resized. I had a good hanlder in v1 that would not over-trigger. It's nice to know the drag event is 100% done before running potentially expensive resize (lots of viz just point their resize to re-render).

Not sure if this is the right forum for suggesting this, but would it be useful to allow users to log activity to Google Analytics, Snowplow Analytics or Google tag manager? 

Most webmasters are very familiar with monitoring site performance and activity in there. Would reduce the writes on the database too... 

If people need more detailed logs they could store them to disk via Nginx.

Thoughts?

@kingo55 sounds like they are 2 different kinds of logs. This table is used in the superset internally to provide some insights for the creators:
* views per dashboards
* views per slice etc
And it can be used to personalize user experience
Having all this data outside the service will make things a bit more complicated.

Providing a way to load the data to external services - is pretty good idea, however we do not have such a use case internally
LGTM once build is green

@vera-liu  - please add a test plan to features
it simplifies the review process and explains how the feature was tested

I have made a proof of concept that works behind a proxy.

The python code changes were fairly straightforward by switching hard coded urls for Flasks' `url_for`.

The JS though... I just did the hacky thing by templating `serverRoot` and `staticRoot` global js variables that are then used to build the urls. It works fine, but is probably not the best.

I would love to contribute this back, but need some guidance on how to approach the JS side of things.
@joharohl if we have the code i'd say to just open a PR for the python code and we can discuss about the js. We can update the PR later or just open a new one.
@rlei could you please rebase on top of master?
@xrmx sure just rebased.

Note that *from within the container* it looks like the server is reachable:

```bash
$ curl http://localhost:8089/health
curl: (52) Empty reply from server

$ docker exec superset-0-15-0 curl http://localhost:8088/health
OK
```
Do you see the request in superset logs?
Not when the request is coming from the host machine
